required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Ultrasound Versus Fluoroscopic Guided Sacroiliac Joint Injection In Patients With Chronic Sacroiliac Joint Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Ultrasound Versus Fluoroscopic Guided Sacroiliac Joint Injection In Patients With Chronic Sacroiliac Joint Pain

detailed_description.textblock: Comparison of ultrasound guided and fluoroscopic guided sacroiliac joint injection

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Sacroiliac joint injection with local anesthetic and steroid using ultrasound Versus fluoroscopy in sacroiliitis

primary_outcome.description: It measures pain intensity (0 no pain - 10 worst pain imaginable)
It evaluates the physical function (0% minimal disability - 100% bed - bound patient)

secondary_outcome.description: It shows if the patient needs analgesic or not compared to pretreatment (type and dose in mg)

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient satisfaction ( global perceived effect on a 7-point scale (GPE) )
secondary_outcome.description: It shows if the patient satisfied with the procedure or not (1= worst ever - 7= best ever)
It measures the seconds of procedure in both groups

intervention.description: Injection of sacroiliac joint with local anesthetic and steroid

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinical diagnosis of sacroiliitis.
- At least 3 positive physical examination maneuvers [FABER (flexion, abduction, and external rotation), POSH (posterior shear), REAB (resisted abduction), Fortin's finger test],
- Moderate to severe pain (NRS pain score â‰¥ 3/10) refractory to oral anti-inflammatory.
- Age from 18ys to 60ys.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Ages less than 18 or more than 85 years.
- Body Mass Index (BMI) above 35 kg/m2.
- A diagnosis of severe anxiety or depression and other psychological disorders.
- Allergy to local anesthetics or steroids and pregnancy.
- Multiple comorbidities (renal , hepatic, cardiac).
- Coagulation disorder as bleeding tendency and platelet dysfunction.
- Contraindication for prone position or radiological exposure.
- Patient refuse .
- Pain suggestive of bilateral sacroiliac joint involvement (it would have been difficult to assess pain and disability secondary to each SIJ).

results_reference.citation: Benson DA, Cavanaugh M, Clark K, Karsch-Mizrachi I, Lipman DJ, Ostell J, Sayers EW. GenBank. Nucleic Acids Res. 2013 Jan;41(Database issue):D36-42. doi: 10.1093/nar/gks1195. Epub 2012 Nov 27.
